characters: INT. BEAN'S SECRET CIDER CELLAR. NIGHT

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. DAY
dialogues.text: An apple tree stands alone at the top of a hill. A handso fox dressed in an Edwardian-style navy velvet suit leans against it with his arms folded and his legs crossed, che on a reed of wild grass. He holds an apple core in his pa He spits out a seed. He looks off across a meadow that descends into the valley below. A female fox strides briskly up the hill. Her coat is a paler, especially beautiful shade of fox-red, and she wea men's trousers and a dark tunic. Fox says as she approach

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd the doctor say?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Nothing. Supposedly, it's just a twenty- four hour bug. He gave me some pills.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you. You probably just ate some bad gristle. Fox brushes the fur on Mrs. Fox's ears with his paws. The walk together along the crest of the hill to a fork in th path. Fox points:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we take the short cut or the scenic route?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Let's take the short cut.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the scenic route is so much prettier.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, let's take the scenic route.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Great. It's actually slightly quicker, anyway. Fox throws his apple core away over his shoulder and danc quick circle around Mrs. Fox, wrapping his arm around her waist extravagantly and making her laugh as they start of down the scenic route.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FARM. DAY
dialogues.text: A rustic cottage surrounded by a small barn, a tin silo, a rickity windmill. There is a sheep in a little pasture. sign on a rail says Berkus Squab. Fox and Mrs. Fox watch the bushes outside a fence.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: What is a squab?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know what a squab is. It's like a pigeon, I suppose. Anyway, it's a type of bird we can eat. Fox motions toward the edge of the property.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we go through the hole under the horse fence or climb the rail over the bridle path?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Well, I guess the horse fence would be a little safer.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But the bridle path puts us out right next to the squab shack. Mrs. Fox hesitates. She fiddles with her paws. She nods nervously. She shakes slightly. Fox looks at her funny.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's wrong? I've never seen you like this. You're acting all skittish. Don't worry. I've been stealing birds for a living since before I could trot.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK, let's take the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, we'll do the horse fence. You gave me the scenic route already. Fox flashes a smile. He says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: By the way, you look unbelievably beautiful tonight. You're practically glowing. Maybe it's the lighting.

Mrs. Fox is, in fact, glowing, albeit ever so slightly. S stares at Fox enigmatically. Fox touches his paw to her cheek. (NOTE: an alternate version of Mrs. Fox will be used for shot which can be literally lit from within.) With the speed, grace, and precision of athletes, Fox and Mrs. Fox: dart through a hole under a painted fence; race along a thin trail next to a garage; crawl beneath a wind where a blonde woman serves an early dinner, dealing hamburgers like playing cards to three little, blond children; creep past a doghouse where a golden retriever sleeps with an airline sleeping mask over his eyes; and shimmy over a doorway outside a workshop where a blond, bearded farmer hacks into a stump with a hatchet, complet pulverizing it into sawdust. They arrive in front of a wo shed. Fox whistles sharply with a half-chirp and performs rapid reverse-flip with a flourish. Fox lifts a loose board. He looks to Mrs. Fox and puts hi finger to his lips for her to be quiet. She shrugs impatiently. They duck inside. They come back out. Each holds a dead, bloody pigeon in his/her teeth. They start to run away. Fox looks up above them. He stops. He frowns. He takes the pigeon out of his mouth and says curiously, pointing toward the sky:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? I think that's a fox-trap! Look at this.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Get away from there.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is it spring-loaded? Yeah... (pointing to different spots) I guess if you come from over there, and you're standing at the door to the squab shack, this little gadget probably triggers the -- (gesturing to Mrs. Fox) Move out of the way, darling. That's right where it's going to land. Mrs. Fox runs back to Fox and tugs at his arm.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Come on! Stop it! Let's go!

Fox pulls on a little, hanging wire. A chain unrolls rapi from a pulley, and a steel cage falls slap down on top of them. A small tag on the base of it says Badoit et Fils. and Mrs. Fox stand motionless, side by side, in disbelief

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, it just falls straight down right here, doesn't it? I guess it's not spring- loaded. Sounds come from around the farm: the dog barks, doors op voices yell, lights come on. Mrs. Fox turns to Fox and sa

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant. Fox stares at Mrs. Fox. He is confused but moved.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. We're going to have a cub. Honey, that's great news!

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: If we're still alive tomorrow morning, I want you to find another line of work. Pause. Fox nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of the entire valley. There are thick woods, green and yellow fields, two ponds, a small village, and river running through the middle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 2 YEARS LATER ( 12 Fox-Years)

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HOLE. DAY
dialogues.text: The entrance to a tunnel under a dirt mound covered with holly bushes.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOLE. DAY
dialogues.text: A small, comfortable kitchen off a living room with two bedrooms behind it. Fox sits at the kitchen table reading newspaper called the Gazette. His fur has gone grey at th temples, and he now wears a dark, double-breasted, pin- striped suit with a conservative necktie. Mrs. Fox stands the counter-top stirring something in a bowl with a whisk
She is dressed in a paint-splattered, cream-colored, Victorian-style dress.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A column in the newspaper with Fox's picture at the top o it. The caption reads: Fox about Town with Fantastic Mr.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Does anybody actually read my column? Do your friends ever talk about it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course. In fact, Rabbit's ex- girlfriend just said to me last week, "I should read Foxy's column," but they don't get the Gazette. (yelling into the next room) Ash! Let's get cracking!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why would they? It's a rag-sheet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to say I hate my job, but that would make it seem more important to me than I want people to think it is. Mrs. Fox puts down her bowl and starts slicing a loaf of bread. A small, narrow fox cub comes out of one of the bedrooms wearing white pants and no shirt. His hair is smashed all onto one side sticking up wrong. He is Ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You're not sick.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a temperature. Mrs. Fox goes quickly over to Ash and puts her paw to his forehead.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You don't have a temperature. Ash turns away and says as he goes back into his bedroom:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to go.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Hurry up. You're going to be late. Mrs. Fox goes back into the kitchen and starts making toa and coffee. Fox whispers to her:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love the way you handled that. Mrs. Fox looks at Fox sideways. She says loudly to Ash:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Your cousin Kristofferson's coming first thing tomorrow morning. I want you to be extra nice to him, because he's going through a very hard time right now, OK? Ash comes back out of his bedroom. He now wears a white cardigan and white socks with his white pants tucked into them. He says aggressively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where's he going to sleep?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: We're going to make a bed for him in your room tonight.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can't spare the space. Put him in Dad's study. Fox says without looking up from his newspaper:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad's study is occupied by Dad. Ash goes back into his bedroom. Fox lowers his newspaper. looks around the room. He says to Mrs. Fox:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to live in a hole anymore. It makes me feel poor. Mrs. Fox stops buttering the toast. She looks to Fox and

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: We are poor -- but we're happy. Fox twists his paw in the air, indicating:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Comme-ci, comme-ga. Anyway, the views are better above ground. Mrs. Fox nods. She brings Fox a plate of toast and a cup coffee. Fox takes her paw and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm seven non-fox-years old now. My father died at seven and a half. I don't want to live in a hole anymore, and I'm going to do something about it. Fox kisses Mrs. Fox's paw. He suddenly eats three slices toast in a second and a half, savagely but neatly. He sta and picks up his cup of coffee.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm off. Fox throws back the last of his coffee, kisses Mrs. Fox o the back of her neck, grabs his briefcase, tucks his newspaper under his arm, and walks to the door. He shouts

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Have a good day, my darlings! Ash comes out the bedroom again. He has now added a white cape to his ensemble and is in the middle of brushing his teeth. There is toothpaste all over his mouth. He waves briefly to Fox and goes back into his bedroom. Fox looks puzzled.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's he wearing? Mrs. Fox shrugs. She smiles sadly and waves to Fox. Fox w back. He starts to go out but pauses to look down at a fo up section of his newspaper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A clipping from the real estate section. There is a photograph of a wide, sprawling beech tree at the top of hill. A caption below it reads: Tree Living, Great Views, Classic Beech

dialogues.speaker: INT. TREE. DAY
dialogues.text: A door opens into a wide, low space with peeling paint. T is an old chair against the wall, a bare light bulb hangi
from the ceiling, and a layer of dust over everything. A skinny weasel in a khaki outfit immediately starts in as comes into the living room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Obviously, it's first growth, indigenous. Original dirt floor, good bark, skipping stone hearth -- Weasel is interrupted by a loud banging clank. He and Fox peer into the next room. A heavy-set opossum with a cowli tinkers with some pipes under the kitchen sink. He is Kyl Weasel snaps at him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd I tell you? I'm showing the property. You're not supposed to be here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (checking his watch) Oh, cuss. What time is it? I'm sorry. Weasel sighs. He waves his arm in Kylie's direction and s distractedly, slightly annoyed:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is Kylie. He's the super. (aside to Fix) He's a little -- Weasel makes a fluttering gesture with his paw. Fox nods. points at a bucket on the floor next to Kylie among bolts tools, and washers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's in the bucket, Mr. Kylie?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just minnows. You want one?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Certainly. Thank you. Kylie reaches into his bucket and hands Fox a live, wrigg minnow. Fox swallows it whole. Fox stares out the window at three sprawling poultry compounds in the distance. Black smoke pours out of a farmhouse chimney on each property. A sign on a water tow in the first compound reads Boggis Farms and has a pictur a chicken on it. A sign on a silo in the second compound reads Bunce Industries and has a picture of a goose on it sign on a windmill in the third compound reads Bean, inc.
(since 1976) and has a picture of a turkey with an apple it. Weasel says pointedly from across the room:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: May I ask what you do for a living, Mr. Fox? Fox's eyes narrow as he looks out, entranced, with his mo slightly open. He says almost inaudibly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to steal birds, but now I'm a newspaper man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, sure. I've seen your by-line. Fox snaps out of his reverie and says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good afternoon, gentlemen. Fox shakes hands abruptly with Weasel and starts across t room. Weasel is about to ask something when Fox stops in doorway, looks back, and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, and Kylie -- thank you for the minnow. It was superb. Kylie smiles. Fox exits.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIVER. DAY
dialogues.text: A beaver dam across a bend in a fast stream. A still pond sits above it. There is an entrance tunnel tucked beneath rock.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEAVER DAM. DAY
dialogues.text: A large room of twig, stick, and mud construction. A card the door reads Badger, Beaver, and Stoat, L.L.P, Attorney Law. An anxious badger sits at his desk reviewing some documents. Fox paces the floor with his hands clasped beh his back.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't buy this tree, Foxy. You're borrowing at nine and a half, which stinks like cuss, plus moving into the most dangerous neighborhood in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: country for someone of your type of species.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're exaggerating, Badger.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bull-cuss! I'm sugar-coating it, man! This is Boggis, Bunce, and Bean! Three of the meanest, nastiest, ugliest farmers in the history of this valley! An uneasy otter secretary peers in at them from the outer office. Fox looks intrigued.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Really? Tell me about them. Silence. Badger sighs. He loosens his tie and settles in.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right...

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fat man with a huge moustache. He wears a tweed suit wh stretches at the buttons so much that they look like they about to snap off. He holds a carbine rifle. He stands in front of his farm, which contains row upon row of chicken houses. He has an ugly face. He is Boggis.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Walter Boggis is a chicken farmer. Probably the most successful in the world.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BOGGIS' KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Boggis sits at a chopping block tearing into a boiled chi with a fork and a meat cleaver.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's unbelievably fat -- which maybe is genetic -- but he also eats three boiled chickens smothered with dumplings every day for breakfast, lunch, supper, and dessert. That's twelve in total, per diem.
Boggis' ear. Furry black and white hairs grow out of it. fly buzzes around, lands on it, and crawls inside. Boggis sticks his pinky in after it and scratches.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He never takes a bath, as a result of which his ear holes are clogged with all kinds of muck and wax and bits of chewing gum and dead flies and so on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A short, overweight man with one slightly wandering eye. wears overalls and a cap. He holds a twelve-gauge shotgun stands in front of his farm, which consists of several lo buildings in rows like a factory. He has a nasty face. He Bunce.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Nathan Bunce is a duck and goosefarmer. He owns about 2 million ducksand 500,000 geese. You might say he's kind ofa pot- bellied dwarf of some kind.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. SWIMMING POOL. DAY
dialogues.text: Bunce stands up to his nose in water. The depth reads 4FT

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's so short his chin would probably be under water in the shallow end of any swimming pool on the planet.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BUNCE'S KITCHEN. DAY
dialogues.text: Bunce sits on two stacked telephone books on a chair. He a dead goose, cutting out its liver and mashing it with a fork. A plate of doughnuts cools on the table.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He eats only doughnuts with smashed-up goose livers injected into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A tall, skinny man in a long trench-coat. He holds a Luge pistol. He stands in front of his farm, which is an apple orchard that stretches over thousands of acres. He has a face. He is Bean.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Franklin Bean is a turkey and apple farmer. He keeps his birds in an orchard
BADGER (V.0.) (cont'd) where they run around squawking and gobbling, surrounded by apples. Bean aims his Luger and shoots a humming bird. Crazy turk run about among the trees.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEAN'S SHED. DAY
dialogues.text: Bean works at a moonshine-type cider still, boiling chemi and sipping from a bottle.

dialogues.speaker: BADGER, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: He's probably anorexic, because he never eats anything. He's on a liquid diet of strong, alcoholic cider, which he makes from his apples. He's as skinny as a pencil, as smart as a whip -- and easily the biggest cusshole I've ever met in my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and Badger in Badger's office.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In summation, I think you just got to not do it, man. That's all.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I understand what you're saying, and your comments are valuable, but I'm going to ignore your advice. Badger leaps out of his chair and slams the office door. points his finger at Fox and screams:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cuss you are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The cuss am I? Fox jumps up and points back at Badger, screaming:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't cussing point at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you cussing with me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do I look like I'm cussing with you? Fox and Badger begin to snarl and snap savagely, knocking into the furniture as they circle around the room pointin each other's faces. Suddenly, they calm down all at once, sighing deeply. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One last thing: something's probably about to happen to me at work which I can't put my finger on but have a funny feeling about. How can I protect myself legally?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you about to get fired?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slash quit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A door with a frosted glass window. Letters painted on it read Gazette, Editor-in-Chief, Phillip Squirrel. Fox's silhouette stands across from that of a small squirrel sitting at a desk. The squirrel's silhouette says in a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're fired.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Slash I quit. Here's my letter of resignation. Fox's silhouette throws an envelope onto the squirrel's d

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two muskrats in orange moving company uniforms unloads bo and furniture from a wagon and carries them into the tree Fox holds open the front door and barks orders at them. Two muskrats in white painter's uniforms paints the walls the living room and the trim around the windows with roll and brushes. Fox stands on the drop-cloth and barks order them.

Two muskrats in blue electrician's uniforms work in the kitchen. Mrs. Fox watches over their shoulders and barks orders at them. Fox holds up a pair of flowered curtains in front of a window. He looks to Mrs. Fox. She stares at the curtains thoughtfully. She raises an eyebrow. Fox and Mrs. Fox sit in the windowsill looking out at the sunset. Ash stands in-between them. The flowered curtains wave in the breeze. Fox puffs on a pipe. Ash blows a soap bubble. Mrs. Fox puts out her paw and a butterfly lands o it. She smiles at Fox. He puts his arm around her. He rai a pair of binoculars to his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A binocular shot of an industrial shack with Boggis Chick House #1 stencilled on the front of it. Fox lowers the binoculars. His eyes sparkle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREE. DAY
dialogues.text: Ash stands poised on a high branch over an inflatable swimming pool printed with a red-tartan plaid pattern. He wears over-sized swim trunks with a pattern of acorns pri on them. Fox sits in the grass eating an apple below with Mrs. Fox. She is painting at an easel. Ash yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this, Dad! Fox looks up. Ash leaps into the air and does a spectacul awkward back-flip during which he appears to have four ar and three legs randomly attached to his body, flailing wildly. He hits the water by the side of his head and sma into the surface back-first with a pained yelp. Fox grima He claps mildly. (NOTE: an alternate version of Ash with four arms and thr legs randomly attached to his body will be used for this stunt.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good jump, Ash! Remember to keep your tail tucked! Fox looks at Mrs. Fox's canvas. It is a picture of the po and landscape in severe weather with black clouds and lightning bolts. It is signed Felicity Fox. Fox raises an eyebrow.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Still painting thunderstorms, I see. Fox sees a small, Samsonite suitcase on the ground next t pair of yellow sneakers. He frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Whose suitcase is that? A boy's voice shouts from the high tree branch:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hello, everyone! Good afternoon! Fox, Mrs. Fox, and Ash look up, surprised. A second Fox c stands poised on the edge of the limb. He is taller, lean sleeker, and it is immediately apparent even by his postu infinitely more graceful than Ash. He is Kristofferson. H wears a professional Speedo with a patch on it that says Team. Fox brightens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson! Welcome to our little tree! I see you brought your swimming trunks! Kristofferson steps off the branch and performs a reserve but perfect jack-knife. He enters the water splashlessly. leaps to his feet, applauding with his paws above his hea whistling and hollering:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at that! This kid's a natural! I'm speechless, Kristofferson! Kristofferson smiles modestly and shrugs. Ash stares at h stonily. Fox turns to Mrs. Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Plus, he knows karate.

dialogues.speaker: INT. LIVING ROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: Fox sits in his armchair reading the Gazette. Ash sits on braided rug on the floor beside him reading a comic book called The Adventures of White Cape. On the cover, there picture of a ferret leaping off a motorcycle. Mrs. Fox is the kitchen in the background flattening a hunk of dough a rolling pin. Kristofferson is in the next room practici tae-kwon-do. He wears khaki shorts, yellow sneakers, and blue, short-sleeved, button-down shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you think I'm an athlete?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (without looking up) What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, I think I'm an athlete, and sometimes I feel like you guys don't see me that way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the sub-text here? Ash thinks for a minute. He looks at Kristofferson in the next room. Kristofferson is now sitting Indian-style on t floor meditating. His paws are turned upward with his thu touching his index fingers forming a ring. Ash says loudl Mrs. Fox in the kitchen:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long is Kristofferson supposed to stay with us?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Until your uncle gets better.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but roughly how long do we plan to give him on that? Double-pneumonia isn't even really that big of a deal, is it? In the background, Kristofferson stands up again and star practicing violent karate kicks. Mrs. Fox leans into the doorway and whispers forcefully:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: As a matter of fact, it is. He's lucky to be alive. Now --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right, but -- Kristofferson yells suddenly as he does a spinning double kick with a chop:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-ya! Everyone looks startled. Kristofferson resumes his tae-kw do practice with an angry, wounded look on his face. Mrs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Lower your voice, Ash.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. TREE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie sit in a porch swing on one of the middle branches of Fox's tree. They drink cups of coffee. Cricke chirp.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kids are crazy, aren't they? You got to try it, though. Raising a family.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Sometimes I feel like maybe I

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What do you think of this tree, by the way? It's great, huh?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. No, I was just saying how some-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have one last part of what I was about to say.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Go ahead.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going broke. You want to help me steal some chickens?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox's study, the next morning. A map of the valley with n and arrows written all over it is spread across a desk. T door is closed with a towel jammed under it. A cricket ma plays loudly on the radio. Fox sits in his armchair. Kyli sits in a creaky rocking chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I used to do this professionally, and I was very successful at it. I had to get out of it for personal reasons, but I've decided to secretly quit my job slash got fired to pursue it again. I'm bringing you in as my secretary and personal assistant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is actually kind of a big deal, so don't just say, "OK!"

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Well, thank you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (clearing is throat) I'm going totape this formyrecords,so don't make a lot of sounds --meaning stop rocking.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, maybe we ought to turn off the radio, then. That's noisier than --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want people to eavesdrop on us, Kylie. Let me just tell this. Kylie stops rocking. Fox presses record on a tape recorde

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Master Plan. Phase one. Side A.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night. Fox stands on a rock at the edge of the woods looking through his binoculars. He lowers them and gives hand-signal. Kylie joins him, and they start out along th moonlit ridge. Fox wears a dark car-coat and a black cap. Kylie has on a navy ski-hat.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: We'll start with Boggis' Chicken House #1. His only security is a few old hunting beagles and a low stone wall. Now a word about beagles: never look a beagle directly in the eye. And if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?
Fox and Kylie in Fox's study earlier that afternoon. Kyli

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beagles aren't so tough.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah? Well, first of all, one of these beagles has chronic rabies, which he's on medication for, and if you get bit by him you have to get shots in your stomach for six months. And, second -- listen, I'm not going to justify this to you. Just pay attention and stop interrupting me. I'm taping this.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RAVINE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie shimmy down a steep embankment and cross a stream.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: I picked some blueberries, butterflied them with a scalpel, and laced each one with ten milligrams of high-potency sleeping powder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox's paws meticulously sprinkle a powdered mickey into a dissected blueberry and stitch it shut with red thread.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Enough to tranquilize a charging gorilla.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie in Fox's study earlier that afternoon. They smoke pipes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How do we make them eat it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling, with utter certainty) Beagles love blueberries.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. RIDGE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie push through a bramble and climb to the top an elderberry bush. Fox looks through his binoculars.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: If we approach with the wind in our faces, we'll smell the chicken livers on Boggis' breath from at least fifty yards away.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARNYARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Seventy-five chickens stand around quietly but anxiously, darting wildly nervous looks at one another. They eat bit grain off the ground.

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (V.O.)
dialogues.text: Remember: they aren't very smart, but they're incredibly paranoid -- so always kill a chicken in one bite.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie in Fox's study earlier that afternoon. They drink whiskey sours. Fox repeats:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One bite, get it? Fox waits for Kylie to respond. Kylie does not. Fox frown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you listening to me? I look into your eyes and I can't tell whether you're getting anything I'm saying. Kylie stares at Fox vacantly. He shrugs. (NOTE: an alternate set of eyeballs will be used for any shots indicating Kylie's vacant look.)

dialogues.speaker: EXT. MEADOW. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie move swiftly through the tall grass. Fox pa to sniff the air. He nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A few beagles, as we discussed, but we're ready for that. Fox and Kylie cross a dirt lane and come out of a shallow ditch. Fox licks the pinky of his paw and holds it up in air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You feel that? The wind's in our faces.
Kylie touches his face with his paw. He nods. Fox and Kyl run along the edge of the ditch. Kylie says casually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah, back in the old days, didn't they used to do a thing where if somebody saw a wolf, and --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What wolf? Fox stops in his tracks. His eyes dart about. Kylie looks him curiously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, nothing? Never mind. Fox and Kylie veer off into shorter grasses. Fox points ahead, regaining his composure:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here comes the low stone wall. Not a problem. Fox and Kylie climb over a low stone wall and find themse at the base of a chain-link fence eleven feet high.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is a chain-link fence, I guess. Did I not remember this? Maybe it's new. Let's pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the cuss? Where'd this giant fence come from? We had a master plan! Kylie motions to a yellow, plywood lightning bolt posted the fence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's this lightning bolt stand for?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a second! I said, "Let's pause"! Pause. Fox pulls himself together. He turns to look at th plywood lightning bolt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That, I guess, hypothetically, could mean maybe this fence might be electric.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I just hope it doesn't mean thunder. I have a phobia of that. Fox and Kylie climb a tree and crouch at the end of one o its branches. Fox produces a zip-loc bag filled with blueberries with white thread stitched into them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch this. Fox puts a blueberry into the end of a straw and shoots i out into the barnyard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The blueberry landing on the ground in front of Chicken H #1. A beagle approaches it and sniffs at it. He eats it. looks very pleased. He falls over, out cold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox with an ecstatic expression on his face. He rapidly shoots more and more blueberries across the barnyard. Bea eat blueberries and fall over, one after another. Fox and Kylie drop down into the barnyard and head for Chicken Ho #1. Fox whispers excitedly as they run:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beagles love blueberries! Didn't I tell you? The master plan's working again! Kylie raises his fist enthusiastically and trips over an unconscious beagle. He picks himself up quickly, and they weave among the rest of the beagles. They reach the entra to the chicken house, open the door, and duck inside. Pause. There is an eruption of crazed squawking, screamin and fighting from inside. The chicken house rumbles. Ligh jolt on across the compound. An alarm goes off. Voices ye The chicken house door swings open again, and Fox and Kyl emerge among a cloud of feathers. Fox carries two dead chickens, and Kylie has one live one. Fox yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said one bite, cuss it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying! I have a different kind of teeth from you! I'm an opossum!
Kylie tries to bite the chicken on the neck. The chicken unharmed. Kylie shrugs. Fox kills the chicken with one qu flick of the jaws. Kylie looks horrified.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's so grisly! There's blood and everything!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're killing chickens! There's going to be blood in this story! Follow me! Fox and Kylie dash to the electric fence. They stop in fr of it. Kylie looks to Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's the master escape plan? Fox hesitates, confused. A gunshot fires from among the chicken houses. Fox shouts to Kylie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Follow me again! Fox and Kylie run back across the barnyard, past the beag as they begin to wake up and stagger around. Farmhands appear, loading shotguns and running into the confusion. and Kylie race by, unnoticed, among them. They dart into house through a flap in the back door. The lights are out the kitchen. They take a moment, breathing hard in the darkness. Kylie shakes his head in disbelief.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wow. That was amazing. How did we do that? We ran the other way or something.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What happens now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no idea. Fox opens the door-flap a crack. He looks out and sees Bo opening the front gate to let out his beagles and farmhan barking and shooting, as they search for the intruders. F shouts to Kylie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy cuss! They opened the gate! Follow me again! Lightning quick, Fox and Kylie burst out through the door flap, race across the barnyard, and dart through the open gate. Up the road, Boggis screams furiously as he runs wi his pack of beagles and farmhands. Fox and Kylie fly into bushes. As they race through the underbrush Fox says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's hit the five and dime on the way home! We need to make some fake price tags and wrap these chickens in wax-paper so it looks like we got them at the butcher shop! Fox and Kylie howl ecstatically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fox's paw lifts a silver dome off a perfectly roasted chicken with an apple in its mouth. Fox and Mrs. Fox sit at a candle-lit table eating chicken drinking wine. Ash, Kristofferson, and Kylie sit at a slightly miniature table eating chicken and drinking milk Fox laughs hysterically as he tells his wife a story. Win comes out of his nose. Fox and Kylie dash out the door of Boggis' Chicken House carrying three more dead chickens. Lights jolt on. Farmha run out firing shotguns. Fox and Kylie escape through a h cut into the electric fence. Fox and Kylie dash out the window of Bunce's Poultry Barn carrying two dead ducks and a goose. Alarms ring. Farmhan run out firing pistols. Fox and Kylie escape through a ho knocked into a brick wall. Fox and Kylie dash out the gates of Bean's Apple Orchard carrying two dead turkeys and a basket of apples. Automat doors close. Farmhands run out firing rifles. Fox and Kyl escape through a hole chopped into a burning barricade. Fox and Kylie run full-speed through a clover field in th dark. The camera zooms in slowly on their faces as they f a stream, leap a fallen hawthorn, and cross into the will glade. They look exhilarated.

dialogues.speaker: INT. KITCHEN. EVENING
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fox studies a crayon price-tag labelled $4 attached wax-paper-wrapped parcel. She opens the parcel and holds dead chicken by the leg. There is a small metal clip arou its ankle. She examines it. She frowns. Fox comes in, grabs an apple out of a bowl, and starts ba out of the room.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Where'd you get this chicken?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I picked it up at the Five-and-Dime last night on my way back from --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: It's got a Boggis Farms tag around its ankle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Huh. Must've escaped from there before I bought it.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DINING ROOM. EVENING
dialogues.text: Ash, Kristofferson, and Kylie sit at the children's table eating dinner. Next to Ash, there is a small, slightly be up statue of a fox with his front legs raised in the air holding a medal above his head. Kylie points at it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This? Nothing. Just some old trophy I won for being an athlete. Fox and Mrs. Fox sit at the adults' table. Fox guzzles do last sip of wine and says with his mouth full of food:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm supposed to cover this book party at some animal's nest in a tobacco field down the hill, so me and Kylie are going to hop over there and give it a whirl. Don't wait up. Fox pulls his napkin out of his collar, drops it on the table, and stands up. Mrs. Fox asks cooly:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: What's the book?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Some memoir. I'll get him to sign you a copy. Fox kisses Mrs. Fox on the cheek. She looks at him suspiciously.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dinner was -- (doing a little gesture) -- pitch-perfect.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. WOODS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie walk among the trees. They are dressed in t prowling outfits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I spotted a couple of broken burglar bars underneath the back door to Bean's secret cider cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're breaking into Bean's house?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cellar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he lives?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where he keeps the cider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Below where he lives. Ash, dressed in his own prowling outfit, is walking with and Kylie. Fox stops short:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you come from? Go back to the tree and do your homework!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to help you steal some cider.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're going to a book party! And keep your mouth shut about any cider, because no one ever said that! Get out of here!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Dad --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But nothing! You're going to get me in a lot of trouble! The three animals stand in silence for a minute. Fox poin to his tree. Ash turns and starts back home. Fox shakes h head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where the cuss does that kid get off? Can you believe that? How'd he get tipped off? You think he's going to tell on us? Fox turns to Kylie. Kylie looks back at him vacantly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Before we go any further, from now on can you give me some kind of signal once in a while just so I know any of this is getting through to you? Pause. Kylie makes a slight motion with his paw. Fox hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Was that it? OK.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BARNYARD. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie dart across the yard and around the back of Bean's farmhouse. Kylie whispers as they run:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One time this wolf --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with all the wolf talk? Can we give it a rest, for once? Fox climbs onto a garbage pail and pulls open a window shutter. He and Kylie shimmy in-between two bent burglar bars.

dialogues.speaker: INT. BEAN'S SECRET CIDER CELLAR. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A vast, damp, gloomy cellar with hundreds of glass jars stacked from floor to ceiling. Each jar is marked Cider. and Kylie come inside and quietly drop to the brick floor

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at all this apple juice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Apple juice? Apple juice? We didn't come here for apple juice. This is some of the strongest, finest alcoholic cider money can buy -- or that can even be stolen. It burns in your throat, boils in your stomach, and tastes almost exactly like pure, melted gold.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's crack open one these 'shine jars and do a shooter. A match strikes in the darkness. Fox and Kylie look aroun the room frantically. On the highest shelf, peering out f behind a huge jar, they see an enormous rat in a striped shirt with a lit match in his claw. He puts the flame in mouth to snuff it out and holds the matchstick in his tee He is longer than a fox and wiry, but with a small pot-be He wears a black beret and moves like a beatnik. He takes a draw from a small rubber tube inserted in the of his cider jar. He says with a slightly sinister New

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all are trespassin', now. Illegally. 'Round these parts, we don't take kindly to cider poachers. Fox and Rat stare at each other. Fox says, finally:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You've aged badly, Rat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're gettin' a little long in the tooth, yourself, partner. Rat spins around and hurls himself scuttling over a shelf down the wall, and through the air onto the brick floor a Fox's feet. He flicks open a switchblade and brandishes i He hisses.
Kylie shrieks and darts into a hole where a brick is miss in the wall. Fox takes an old-fashioned boxing stance.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How's your old lady doin'? Kylie peers out from his hole in the wall nervously. Fox Rat circle each other slowly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you refer to my wife?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: She was the town tart, in her day. Wild and foot-loose and pretty as a mink stole. She was a creme brulee -- until you made an honest woman out of her, Mr. Fox. Kylie says, intrigued, from his hole:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that true?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, not. I mean, certainly, she lived. We all did. It was a different time. Let's not use a double-standard. She marched against the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But town tart?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shut up. Rat lunges at Fox with his switchblade. Fox dodges nimbly cocks an eyebrow and smiles:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That was close, Rat. Be careful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, I'm as careful as a -- A door at the top of the stairs opens suddenly with a lou creak. Rat and Fox look terrified. They both dart away an hide behind cider jars. A heavy-set, middle-aged housekeeper carrying a rolling p comes down the stairs and walks straight over to the shel where Fox is hiding.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How many jars should I bring up, ma'am? A strong, almost masculine woman's voice answers from

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. Two, I guess. The housekeeper grabs the two jars directly next to the o Fox is hiding behind and tucks them under her arm. Fox te his body. He shivers slightly. A graze of the red fur of arm sticks out barely from behind his jar. The housekeepe hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He drank three yesterday, ma'am.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right, take three. The housekeeper grabs Fox's jar. Fox closes his eyes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, don't. The housekeeper stops with her hand on the neck of Fox's

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three's too many. It's unhealthy. He's anorexic. Bring two. The housekeeper lets go of Fox's jar. Fox relaxes slightl The housekeeper grabs Fox's jar again. Fox tenses up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But maybe, just in case --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Two's plenty. The housekeeper lets go of Fox's jar and walks away. She back up the stairs and closes the door. Kylie says in the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, my cuss. That was like a scene out of

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The door opens again. An exceptionally tall, powerfully b woman in a black dress and Wellingtons, with grey hair pu back in a bun, bright green eyes, and a meat cleaver tuck under her apron strings comes swiftly down the stairs. Sh
eyeballs the corners of the room. She is Mrs. Bean. She s thickly (in her masculine voice):

dialogues.speaker: MRS. BEAN
dialogues.text: To whom it may concern: if I catch a rat in a black beret drinking Mr. Bean's secret cider without his express permission, I intend to chop said rat's head off, brine it, pickle it, and bake it in a vermin casserole. I hope this clarifies my position on the matter. Sincerely, Evelyn Bean. Mrs. Bean turns and goes back up the stairs. She closes t door. Pause. Rat's voice says from the shadows:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dear Mrs. Bean, your language, while somewhat purple, is nevertheless impossible to misinterpret. However -- comma -- given the proximity of said rat at the moment of your -- The door at the top the stairs opens again. Silence.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie running away from Bean's farmhouse with two jars of cider. They both look badly shaken. A gunshot rin out taking us to:

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEAN FARMS. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Bean is standing darkly in his front doorway. Smoke drift from the end of his Luger, pointed at the ceiling. A brok light bulb hangs from a wire above his head. Boggis and B sit together on the porch in rocking chairs, startled, staring at Bean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to give a speech, and at the end of it -- I'm going to throw a twist into this plot. Bean lights a cigarette and begins to walk slowly around porch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First truth: this is the most ambitious fox we've ever encountered, bar none. Bean spins around and shoots out a second light bulb. Bog and Bunce look uneasy. Bean continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Second truth: the meaning of ambition is defined in the dictionary. Bean jumps and rolls and shoots out a third light bulb.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Third truth: the weakness of the ambitious man is his Achilles heel -- Bean quickly shoots out three more light bulbs behind his back, over his shoulder, and between his legs. The porch dark. He flicks on a flashlight and points it in his two colleague's faces. They look scared. Bean says urgently:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but I've already figured out where this fox lives, and tomorrow night we're going to camp in the bushes, wait for him to come out of the hole in his tree, and shoot the cuss to smithereens. How's that grab you, fellas? Boggis and Bunce hesitate. They nod and murmur their approval.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOX'S TREE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie come quietly into the half-lit kitchen dres in their prowling outfits. They walk to the door.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Another book party? Fox and Kylie turn around, startled. Mrs. Fox sits on a s in the darkened pantry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Woah! I didn't see you. Sitting in the dark over there. Yeah, no. Actually, there's a fire. I just got the call. They said maybe it's arson? I got to interview the marshall and see what's --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Kylie, is he telling the truth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't want to be put in the middle of this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thanks, Kylie.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: If what I think is happening is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- it better not be.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boggis, Bunce, and Bean waiting crouched in the bushes. B licks his finger and holds it up to test the direction of wind. He nods, points to his nose, and gives a thumbs-up Boggis and Bunce.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOX'S TREE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox pokes his head up out of his hole. He sniffs once. He moves an inch forward and stops. He sniffs again. He wait moment and listens. He steps out of the hole and says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nice job covering for me. Next time

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A twig snaps. Fox freezes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boggis, Bunce, and Bean frozen in the bushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The branches of the trees as the wind suddenly changes it direction.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox on high alert. He rapidly sniffs the air three times row. He turns to a confused Kylie and says, panicking:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All three! Fox and Kylie spin around and dart back into the hole as Boggis, Bunce, and Bean open fire wildly from the bushes. barrage of bullets and buckshot rips into the tree-bark. Silence.

Smoke from the three guns floats upward in the night air. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean approach the tree. Bean shines hi flashlight on Fox's hole. In the circle of light on the ground lies the tattered, b stained remains of Fox's tail. Bean picks it up and holds in the air in front of Boggis and Bunce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We got the tail, but we missed the fox. Pause. Bean takes out his walkie-talkie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petey? You and the boys sober up and get out here on the A.S.A.P. Bring eleven shovels, three pick-axes, 500 rounds of ammunition, and a bottle of apple cider.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FOX'S TREE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fox licks the stump of Fox's tail and mends it with gauze and medical tape. She looks furious. Kylie and the cubs watch, concerned. Ash says uncertainly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It'll grow back, won't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) Tails don't grow back, except for lizards.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Tails don't grow back. I'm going to be tail-less for the rest of my life.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, anyway, it's not half as bad as double-pneumonia, right? (pointing to Kristofferson) His dad's got one foot in the grave and one foot on a banana peel. That's a lot worse than -- Kristofferson hurls an acorn violently onto the floor. It ricochets off a wall and into a teacup. Everyone falls silent. Kristofferson turns away.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, everyone. I'm going to go meditate for half an hour. Kristofferson walks out of the room. Mrs. Fox looks at As and says angrily:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You've got twenty-nine minutes to come up with a proper apology. Ash crosses his arms in front of his chest and stares straight ahead into space grimly. Fox says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's with the crazy outfit? Why a cape and the pants tucked into your socks? Ash does not respond. Fox sighs. Mrs. Fox finishes bandag his tail. Fox goes over to the wall and stands with his b to the room.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got fired slash quit the Gazette and started stealing chickens on the sly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That tail was the first thing I ever noticed about you. It was easily the most attractive tail for at least 50 miles in every direction. It was probably your single best quality -- and now it's gone forever.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox lying in bed staring at the ceiling in the dark next Mrs. Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why the cuss didn't I listen my lawyer? At this point we'll be lucky if we can flip this tree for half of what we've already sunk into it. Fox flips over onto his stomach.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I won't be able to sleep on my back for six weeks -- and on my stomach I feel congested. Why the cuss didn't I listen to my lawyer?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because you don't listen to anybody.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (sitting up suddenly) What was that?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I said -- There is a quiet scraping sound from above. Fox jumps out bed. He hollers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wake up! Everybody! They're digging us out! There is a scrunch and then a loud thump from above. Mrs. looks at Fox intensely:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: They'll kill the children!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Over my dead body, they will.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's what I'm saying! You'd be dead, too, in that scenario!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I'm arguing against that!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you talking about?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why are you yelling at me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop! Stop! Stop! Fox and Mrs. Fox turn quickly to Kylie standing in the doorway with a red blanket wrapped around his shoulders.
and Kristofferson stand behind him. They look terrified. Kylie shouts in a pained voice:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You say one thing, she says another, and it all changes back again! The point of a shovel pierces the ceiling. Everyone looks and stares in shock. Fox suddenly leaps across the room w a wild energy, scrambles halfway up a wall, and throws ov two chairs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got it! There's not a moment to lose! Why didn't I think of this before?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Think of what?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Think of the one thing a fox does quicker than a man, quicker than any other animal in the world! (at the top of his lungs)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Everyone digging furiously. Dirt flies everywhere. The sh booms down into the ground, among the roots of the tree, through buried pebbles, layers of soil, and subterranean mineral deposits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The shot stops at the bottom of a dark hole deep, deep underground. Mrs. Fox lies on the floor, breathing heavil with a lit lantern at her side. The cubs are sprawled out around her. Kylie leans in the corner with his shirt off around his waist. Fox stands up and clears his throat. Everyone looks at him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think it's time for me to give us a pep talk and explain some things. (commencing a speech) A very long time ago --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: May I have a word with you privately?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, we're in a hole. Where --

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Just on the other side of this mineral deposit. Follow me. Fox reluctantly follows Mrs. Fox through a crack in the bedrock and into a small air-pocket with glittering quart walls. She wheels on Fox:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: I'm going to lose my temper now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Right now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, when -- Mrs. Fox scratches Fox across the face, slicing a quick sliver into his fur. Fox cringes away with his paws up protectively. He lowers his paws. His eyes fill with tear (NOTE: the scar in Fox's fur never grows back.) Mrs. Fox takes a deep breath. She says:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Twelve fox-years ago, you made a promise to me while we were caged inside that fox- trap that, if we survived, you would never steal another chicken, goose, turkey, duck, or squab, whatever they are. I believed you. Why did you lie to me?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because I'm a wild animal.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You're also a husband and a father.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm trying to tell you the truth about myself.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: I don't care about the truth about yourself. Fox looks down at the ground. He nods and tries to contai his emotions. Mrs. Fox watches him coldly.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: This story is too predictable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Predictable? Really? What happens in the end?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the end, we all die -- unless you change. Mrs. Fox walks out of the air-pocket. Fox stands alone in silence.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. FOX'S TREE. DAY
dialogues.text: The next morning. There is a large hole in the side of th hill, under Fox's tree. The ceiling to the living room ha been completely removed. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean stand ha underground with their heads sticking out of the hole, breathing hard, with dirty shovels over their shoulders. Bunce stands on Fox's tiny club chair.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These foxes dig like a bunch of hyperactive gophers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin? You got another twist for this plot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say that again?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I say you got another -- Bean whips out his walkie-talkie and twirls it like a six shooter. He presses a button on it and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Petey? Get me the current contact info for Earl Malloy on the A.S.A.P.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's Earl Malloy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? You mean over at Malloy Consolidated? Oh, he does rentals.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What does he rent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Three yellow and black, murderous, brutal bulldozer diggi tractors with Malloy Consolidated painted on the sides of them. They make a terrible, high-pitched growling noise a spit black grease and smoke. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean stand among the tractors nodding giddily to each other. They scramble into the drivers' se and begin ripping into the hillside. Bunce sits on a dictionary to see over the dashboard.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox, Mrs. Fox, Kylie, Ash, and Kristofferson digging frantically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tractors grabbing huge chunks of earth and tossing th into the meadow. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean, drunk with digg laugh manically as the controls of their tractors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's kick some fox cuss!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm cussing loving this!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's hyper-cussing-active now? Bean throws his tractor into top gear. The teeth of the g shovels clank against each other, ripping through the tre roots.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A temperature gauge with its needle pushing the limits of red.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A grizzled, white-haired man in a greasy yellow and black jumpsuit and coke-bottle protective eyeglasses. A patch o his pocket says E. Malloy. He watches the farmers digging crazily with the tractors. Sparks from the mayhem reflect dancing on his lenses.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: These machines weren't made to be handled like this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hill with half its earth dug out from under the tree. tree still stands precariously above the wild tractors.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hill now razed with the fallen, old beech tree laying its side as the tractors dig deeper.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The tractors almost completely below ground in a deep cra A crowd of neighbors and local press from the town has gathered and watches as the tractors stop digging and rum up out of the crater. The motors go quiet. Boggis, Bunce, Bean climb down from their tractors. They look angry and tired. They stand among the workers and onlookers. A television reporter with an Action 13 camera crew confr

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Farmer, correct me if I'm misreading the data, you've successfully destroyed the scenery, but the alleged fox remains at large. What will you three prominent farmers do now?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, Dan, I can tell you what we're not going to do. We're not going to let him go.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you concerned about the possibility

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have no further dialogue in this scene. Bean turns away from the reporter and pulls Boggis and Bu aside. He addresses them with calm intensity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not going home until we smoke this son-of-a-cuss out his hole, string him up on a clothesline, and fly him like a kite. Boggis, how many men have you got working on your farm?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-five.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Bunce?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Thirty-six.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: And I've got thirty-seven. That's 108 men altogether. Now what do I got here? Two quitters -- or are you staying with?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That night. A helicopter with a Bean, inc. decal on the s of it circles the crater scanning the dark terrain with a searchlight. There are tents, trucks, and 108 men gathere around the perimeter. They sit on bricks and logs and are armed with bats, pistols, rifles, shotguns, bows and arro and hatchets.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HOLE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox, his family, and Kylie lie exhausted on the floor of their deep hole. The walls are covered with knotted roots vines. Fox says to Kylie:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: One of those slovenly farmers is probably wearing my tail as a necktie by now.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're paranoid, Foxy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Bean sitting in her kitchen watching television next an extremely skinny, freckled twelve year-old boy. The bo points at the screen and laughs to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Look at Dad's tie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The television set. Bean is on-screen with the Action 13 reporter. He wears a fox-fur necktie.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMP. NIGHT
dialogues.text: There is a full moon. Lanterns glow in the farmers' tents group of farmhands sit around a campfire next to the crat One of them cooks a chicken on a spit. Another sits on a playing a banjo. He is Petey. He sings:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 'Bout a handsome little fox Let me sing you folks a yarn. Hey, diddle-dee, doddle-do, doodle-dum! 'Twas a splendid little feller Full of wit 'n' grace 'n' charm. Say, zippy-zee, yappy-yo, google-gum! The shot moves past the leathery faces of the other farmh as they listen: amused, moved, hungry, tired, charmed, annoyed, whistling, playing a jew's harp, trying to sing along but not really knowing the words, etc.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like any little critter needin' Vittels for his littl'uns, Well, he stole, and he cheated, And he lied to survive. Doodle-dum, diddle-die, doddle-diddle- doodle-dee! Zippy-zo, zippy-zay, zippy-zappy- zoopy-zee! (this verse is spoken:) Let me take a little tick now To color in the scene: 'Cross the valley lived three yokels Name of Boggis, Bunce, and Bean.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (back to singing:) Now these three crazy jackies had our hero on the run. Shot the tail off the cuss With a fox-shootin' gun. But that stylish little fox Was as clever as a whip. Dug as quick as a gopher Who was a hyper-ack-a-tive. Now those three farmers sit 'Twhere there's a hole 'twas once a hill. Hey, diddle-dee, doddle-do, doodle-dum! And as far as I can reckon They're a-settin' up there still.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Way, zippy-zee, yappy-yo, google --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What are you singing, Petey? Petey stops short. Everyone turns quickly and sees Bean standing over them in the darkness with his Luger in one and a cigarette in the other. Petey looks nervous.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know. I was just kind of making it up as I was going along... Petey trails off. Bean shakes his head. He looks highly irritated.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's just weak song-writing! You wrote a bad song, Petey! Bean throws his cigarette into the campfire. He storms aw Petey turns to the other farmhands. Everyone looks uncomfortable.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: 3 DAYS LATER (18 Fox-Days)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Morning in the farmers' camp. The cook flips an egg on a skillet. He puts it on a plate with bacon and hands it to Petey. Petey asks him:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: How long can a fox go without food or water?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The exhausted foxes and Kylie underground. Kylie says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I can only answer as an opossum, but I don't think I can last more than another couple of hours before I get completely dehydrated and starve to death.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that? Ash points. Everyone looks. A tiny hole appears in the wa at the end of the tunnel. Dirt crumbles out of it -- and bit of metal catches a glint. Fox and his family watch, frozen. A breath of air blows into the tunnel. The flame on Mrs. Fox's lantern flickers once and goes ou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not a sound! Silence. There is a sudden, loud scrabbling noise. A matc strikes. Fox touches it to Mrs. Fox's lantern-wick. The tiny hole in the wall has become a large one. Badger stands in front of Fox with his law partner Beaver, Beave overgrown, hulking son, a medium-sized mole, and a grey f mouse with a bandana tied in a "do-rag" style around his head. Badger has a spoon in his hand. Fox and Badger erup each other, screaming simultaneously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You scared the cuss out of us!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I told you not to buy at nine and a cussing half!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You don't just bang into somebody's cussing tunnel!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you cussing yelling at me!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're cussing right I'm cussing yelling!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all cussing starving to death because of you, you mangy, cussing, little cuss! Fox and Badger snarl and scratch at each other, circling around the hole. They calm down slightly. Badger continue

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We've been digging in circles for three days. Half the woods've been obliterated. Nobody can get out. Right now my wife's huddled at the bottom of the flint-mine with Mrs. Mole, Mrs. Beaver, Rabbit's ex- girlfriend, no food, no water, and twenty- seven hungry, whining, starving, little animal brats. This is a total cluster- cuss for everybody! Fox looks around the room at the entire gaunt, dirty, emaciated assembly. Everyone stares at him angrily. He swallows. The mole says softly.:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just want to see a little --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- sunshine.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But you're nocturnal, Phil. Your eyes barely even open, on a good day.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sick of your double-talk. We have rights! Beaver's son looms over Ash and Kristofferson in a muddy alcove on the side of the tunnel. He pokes Ash in the che with the finger of his paw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We don't like you, and we hate your dad. You're too snazzy. You dress like a girl. You're creative. Now grab some of that mud, chew it in your mouth, and swallow it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (scared and disgusted) I'm not going to eat mud!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuss, yeah, you are. Beaver's son grabs a handful of mud, smashes it into Ash' mouth, and forces his jaws up and down in a chewing motio Ash coughs and splutters. Kristofferson frowns. He takes his shoes with his feet. He says with a quiet ferocity:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't do that. Beaver's son looks to Kristofferson. He looks down at Kristofferson's feet.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd you take your shoes off?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So I don't break your nose when I kick it. Kristofferson kicks Beaver's son in the face, karate chop his neck, elbow-jabs him twice in the gut, and flips the enormous youth over his shoulder and into the mud. Beaver son gets up, crying, and walks out of the alcove. Ash watches blankly with mud all over his mouth as Kristofferson puts his shoes back on.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can fight my own fights. Badger and Fox stand facing each other at the end of the tunnel. Badger says aggressively:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Those farmers aren't going to quit until they've got you and every member of your family nailed upside-down to a bloody stick with your eyes gorged out.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This is getting a little too personal. Badger waits for Fox to continue. Fox stares into space.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a minute. Fox turns and walks away. He faces the wall of the tunnel sits down on a rock. Everyone watches him uncertainly. Th look at each other. Badger starts to say something, but K cuts him off sharply:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh! Badger falls silent. Fox sits with his chin on his paw, l in concentrated thought. He stands up. He nods repeatedly begins to pace. His eyes dart from one spot to another. H paws move abruptly around in the air drawing lines and shapes. He freezes and looks straight up at the ceiling o the tunnel. He snaps the fingers of his paw and looks to others. He says with a cautious excitement:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got an idea.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What is it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It could be a good one.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Lay it on us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It might save our lives.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Say the idea! Fox looks down at Ash, who stands beside him with mud sti on his mouth. He nods. He says suddenly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Let's try it!
Fox runs over to Mrs. Fox:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Go to the flint-mine. Tell Mrs. Badger, Rabbit's ex-girlfriend, et al. that help is on the way.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is help on the way? Fox grips Mrs. Fox's paw. He looks into her eyes and says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I sure as cuss hope so. Mrs. Fox detects a special, familiar, inspired light in h husband's eyes at this moment. She nods. She hands Ash th lantern. She straightens the neck-line of his cape, licks mud off Ash's snout, and scrambles away down Badger's tun Ash wants to cry but does not. Fox turns to the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Gentlemen, this time we must dig in a very special direction. Fox feels the walls with his paws. Everyone watches attentively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I got to kind of feel out the vibe. Fox stops. He points slightly downwards and due south. He says with quiet anticipation:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Begin. Everyone starts digging, slowly but intently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The diggers one hundred yards later. Fox suddenly whistle and raises his fist. The diggers stop digging. Fox feels the ceiling with his paws. He knocks something hard. It sounds hollow. He look the others with a funny expression and raises an eyebrow. Fox carefully pushes up a floorboard. It creaks loudly. T all duck down and wait. Nothing happens. Fox pushes up a second floorboard. He cautiously pokes his head up throug
the gap. He lets out a shriek of excitement and whispers excitedly down to the others:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've done it! I've done it, first time! Come up and see where you are, my darlings! Everyone scrambles up out of the tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SHED. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Everyone stands in the middle of Boggis' Chicken House #1 The room is teeming with chickens, which stare at them nervously. There are black chickens, white chickens, brow chickens, and one that combines all three colors. Fox

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I hit it slap in the middle! Do you get how incredible this is? The others nod. They look dazed and wild. Fox holds up hi hands and whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't lose your heads, now. Let's do this properly. First, everyone have a drink of water. Fox leads the others over to the chickens' drinking troug They all lap up the cool water. Fox dries his mouth.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox seizes a black chicken violently.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash and Kristofferson running down the tunnel carrying tw dead, black chickens. They turn three corners and arrive the mossy hollow. They look inside.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and the other diggers tunnel under the silo in front Bunce Industries. Cows eat grass in the pasture above. Fox and the other diggers comes out of a hole in the floo and dance an ecstatic jig in a great storeroom lined to t ceiling with plucked ducks and geese. Smoked hams and sid of bacon dangle from the rafters.

Fox and the other diggers tunnel under the windmill in fr of Bean, inc. Sheep eat clover in the field above. Fox and the other diggers comes out of a hole in the floo and dance an ecstatic jig in a corrugated plastic and met pen among dozens of gobbling turkeys. Fox and the other diggers race dancing ecstatically back through the complex network of tunnels carrying dead turk geese, bacon, flour, salt, sugar, jars of cider, and a portable television set.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FLINT-MINE. DAY
dialogues.text: The flint-mine is a large but cozy space with stone walls dirt floor, a small kitchen, and a fireplace. There are r of cots, sleeping bags, boxes, blankets, and suitcases fo all the refugee animals. All the animals have gathered together and drink cider cocktails while small rabbits, skunks, and field mice set the table. The room is festoon with garlands. A well-dressed mole smoking a pipe plays t piano. A bespectacled rabbit leans against it humming a t Weasel stands in the corner talking with Beaver.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What am I going to do? I'm going to hold him to the terms of the contract. It's not my fault they uprooted it. Kristofferson serves cranberry punch from a tureen in the corner. Ash goes over to him and holds out a mug.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They say I owe you an apology for some of the mean things I said about your father's illness. His double-pneumonia or whatever they're calling it now. Kristofferson ladles Ash a cupful.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So there it is. I hope we can continue our relationship as cousins or family members or however you want to define

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (suddenly more intense) -- but do me a favor for yourself. The next time you have a problem with something I've said, come to me as a fox

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: and let's deal with it right then and not let it blow up into a whole, huge thing involving parents and so on. Agreed? Ash drinks his punch in one long sip and holds out the em mug for a refill. Kristofferson nods slowly. He points at with his ladle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to teach you karate. Badger sits next to the fireplace with Fox and Kylie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can imagine how painful, even just emotionally, that must be for you.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, you know, it's not the end of the world.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, but, Foxy, how humiliating! Having your whole tail blown clean off by a --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can we drop it? Kristofferson starts to refill Ash's mug again. Ash sudde puts his paw over the brim. Kristofferson hesitates. Ash raises an eyebrow and says mysterriously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ever tasted one of Mrs. Bean's famous nutmeg-ginger-apple snaps?

dialogues.speaker: EXT. CAMP. DAY
