dialogues.text: A large fire truck drives up to the destroyed hill with firemen hanging off the back and sides. It parks among th tractors and tents. The chief, in a white helmet, goes ov to Boggis, Bunce, and Bean waiting at the mouth of the pi patch on his sleeve says O.W.F.R.P.F. Farmhands and firem circle around.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got me a donation for the old Wounded Fireman's Retirement Pension Fund? Bean pulls a yellow check out of his inside pocket.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right here. (pointing behind him) Let me show you this hole.

dialogues.speaker: INT. FLINT-MINE. DAY
dialogues.text: Candles glow all around. Everyone is seated at the long dining room table, and a magnificent feast with every var of fruit, meat, vegetable, and roasted bird has been laid in front of them. They tear into their meals, eating and drinking ferociously. Crumbs, juices, blood, and bones fl into the air. Jaws snap and chew. There is no conversatio Badger suddenly stands and rings a knife against his cide glass. Everyone looks up, taking a breather from the fren of eating. Badger clears his throat.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, it took a near-catastrophe for all of you to finally take me up on my offer to have you over to the flint-mine for dinner, but I guess we have --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry. Maybe my invitation got lost in the mail. Does anybody know what this badger's talking about? Everyone laughs. Fox sits at the opposite end of the tabl with a crooked smile on his face.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But Clive's right --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- in all seriousness -- (aside, to Badger) -- excuse me, B. Fox raises his cider glass. Badger reluctantly sits back down.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we do have those three ugly, cusshole farmers to thank for one thing: reminding us to be thankful and aware of each other. I'm going to say it again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Aware. Badger whispers to his wife:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foxy cuss-blocked my toast, man.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The hole where Fox's tree once stood. The dead tree lies its side. A fireman slides a thick hose deep into the tun He looks behind him and nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ready. The shot moves backwards along the hose, past seven more firemen signalling to each other with: a thumbs-up, a sna fist in the air, a swirl of the fingers, a peace symbol, OK, and a hook-'em Horns. The shot continues past Boggis, Bunce, and Bean helping to hold the hose in position. Bog growls. Bunce hisses. Bean snarls. The shot arrives at a on the side of the fire truck. The chief points:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let her rip. A fireman cranks a huge wrench on a steel nut. A pressure gauge shoots to maximum. The fire truck and hose begin to vibrate loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash and Kristofferson crouched under a drain-cover pushed just-open next to a refrigerator. They peer out across a bright, clean, white kitchen at a plate of perfect, golde cookies on a counter-top next to an open window with a st ladder directly in front of it. They look at each other. look around the quiet, empty room. Ash shrugs. Ash and Kristofferson dart out, leaving the drain-cover propped-up. They race over the linoleum. They climb the s ladder and stop at the plate. Ash swoons and says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They're still warm. Ash and Kristofferson gather more cookies than they can possibly carry, eating as they collect them. Crumbs go everywhere. On the other side of the room, the drain-cover falls shut with a loud clank. Ash and Kristofferson look up, wildly startled. All at once they hear in a simultaneous cacopho the back door bursting open, a boy and two beagles shouti and barking, the pantry door slamming, Mrs. Bean and her

middle-aged housekeeper clanging pots and pans and arguin timer on the counter-top ringing, and a raven fluttering the windowsill and cawing. Ash and Kristofferson panic silently. They drop the cooki and fly down the step-ladder.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox in mid-toast:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've stepped on some toes and alienated a few of you over the past few days -- but is it wrong for me to suggest we might've done worse than having an incredible banquet in a beautiful flint-mine surrounded by our favorite animals? Look at each other. Here we are. Wow. Now I've already had too much to drink, and I'm feeling sentimental, but I'm going to say something, anyway, which nobody wants to admit, but I think is probably true: we beat 'em. We beat those farmers, and now we're triumphantly eating their roasted chicken, their sizzling duck, their succulent turkey, their foie gras de --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd the boys go? Ash? Kristofferson? (to Mrs. Fox) What am I hearing again, baby? What's happening? Am I still paranoid? There is a low, distant rumbling which rapidly builds to deafening roar. Everyone waits, frozen. A single drop of water drips from the ceiling into Badger's water glass. F turns to Badger and says:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's pause again. A wild deluge smashes into the room flooding the flint-mi and tunnels with a blasting current that sweeps everyone everything away chaotically.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The entire party of well-dressed animals and their plates furniture, chickens, etc. shooting down the tunnel with t rushing waters. Fox, helpless, holding his breath, looks the others underwater: Badger shakes his head in disgust; Rabbit makes a fierce grimace; Mole bares his teeth ferociously; Beaver rants angrily with bubbles coming out his mouth; and Kylie stares ahead vacantly, holding his n
Fox turns sadly to Mrs. Fox. She looks terrified.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The flood blasts out of a wide pipe rocketing the animals into a murky, brick cavern with drainpipes on all sides a three inches of black water on its floor. Fox picks himse up, dazed and scared, and looks around at his soaked frie and their families.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the cuss just happened? Something with water. That was dangerous. Is anyone hurt?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're all hurt! My entire flint-mine just got demolished!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's do a head-count! Everybody pick a buddy! Each animal turns to his neighbor and establishes their b relationship. Fox looks wildly agitated as his eyes dart about, searching. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd the boys go? Ash? Kristofferson? Ash's voice cracks on the other side of the cavern:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm here. Everyone turns to see Ash standing at the mouth of a smal pipe. He looks devastated and terrified. Fox points to hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash! Who's your buddy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson, but I lost him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You lost him? Where were you?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We went for cookies. Everyone turns to Fox. Fox yells desperately:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson! Fox sprints around the cavern, splashing, digging, and ducking in and out of tunnels as the others join his fran search. His voice sounds pained as he shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson! Kristofferson! Kristofferson!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The three farmers standing next to the fire truck. Bean h a soaked, half-conscious Kristofferson up in the air by t tail. Kristofferson is quietly crying.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wrap this wet, little mutt in a newspaper and put him in a box with some holes punched in the top.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Everyone has gathered together. They are all in a state o shock. Fox turns to Mrs. Fox beside him.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your brother's going to kill me, if he survives his double-pneumonia. Beaver runs into the brick cavern out of a drainpipe,

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: There's only one way out of this sewer, but the manhole cover's closed, and there's a station-wagon parked on it -- which means we're permanently stuck down here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You still think we beat 'em, Foxy? Everyone turns to Fox and stares at him coldly. Fox sits on the floor, in the water. He says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Somebody take over. I'm not in charge anymore.
Everyone looks around at each other. They don't know what do. Mrs. Fox sits down in the water next to Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You told me to change, but I can't --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- except, possibly, on some level, I think I just did.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then maybe we're not all going to die. Fox looks to Mrs. Fox. He stands up suddenly. He takes Mr Fox's hand.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse us, everyone. Fox leads Mrs. Fox over to a ledge near a cement waterfal the far side of the brick cavern. He puts his arm around waist.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badger's right. These farmers aren't going to quit until they catch me. I shouldn't have lied to your face. I shouldn't have resigned slash gotten fired from the Gazette. I shouldn't have pushed these farmers so far and tried to embarrass them and cuss with their heads. I enjoyed it, but I shouldn't have done it -- and now there's only one way out. Maybe if I hand myself over and let them kill me, stuff me, and hang me over their

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You'll do no such thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Darling, maybe they'll let everyone else live. Mrs. Fox stares at Fox. She says desolately:

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Why'd you have to get us into this, Foxy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but I have a possible theory. I think I have this thing where I need everybody to think I'm the greatest -- the quote-unquote fantastic Mr. Fox -- and if they aren't completely knocked- out, dazzled, and kind of intimidated by me, then I don't feel good about myself. Mrs. Fox shakes her head and turns away. Fox continues:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Foxes traditionally like to court danger, hunt prey, and outsmart predators -- and that's what I'm actually good at! I think, at the end of the day, I'm just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We're wild animals. Fox smiles sadly and nods. He shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we always were. I promise you: if I had all this to do over again, I'd have never let you down. It was always more fun when we did it together, anyway. Mrs. Fox has tears all over her face. Fox kisses her. He whispers in her ear:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I love you, Felicity.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: I love you, too, but I shouldn't have married you. Mrs. Fox turns and walks away. Fox stares after her. He g over to Ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I ever tell you about the time I learned we were going to have a cub?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In the fox-trap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Right. We were at gun-point, and your

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- says she's pregnant.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let me tell it, OK? I had no idea how we were going to get out of this jam, and then it hit me: what do foxes do better than any other animal?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dig.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You're stepping on my lines.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep telling it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So we dug. And the whole time I put paw over paw, scooping dirt and pebbles with your mother digging like crazy beside me, I kept wondering: who is this little boy going to be?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or girl.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Or girl, right -- because at that point we didn't know. Fox grabs Ash by his shoulders and looks him in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash, I'm so glad he was you. Fox hugs Ash tightly, holds him for an instant, then let' go. He turns to the group.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badger, organize a search party and try to find Kristofferson. Maybe he's alive. I'm sorry, everyone. I wish --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, good-bye. Fox looks across the cavern to Mrs. Fox standing with her back to him. She turns to face him. Her eyes are burning. smiles sadly. He races away down the drain-pipe. Everyone watches him disappear. Badger hesitates. He addresses the

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I guess we should probably split into a certain number of groups and start doing something, right?

dialogues.speaker: INT. CONDUIT. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox sprints full-speed in the darkness. His claws scratch rattling along the iron floor and splash through puddles shallow water. Fox stops suddenly. He stands up tall on his hind legs. H ears perk up. One pins back. He listens.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badger carrying a lantern leading Ash, Mole, and two smal rabbits down a drainpipe. Badger calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson? Hello? Can you hear us? Rat's voice echoes in the darkness:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Y'all lookin' for somethin'? Nothin' down here but rusty bottle-caps and drainin' water. Everyone stops short. Rat drops into the pipe from an overhead drain ahead of them. He says ominously:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They got the boy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Who's got him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The farmers three. You know who I'm talkin' about.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: They've kidnapped him?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well-done, Mr. Badger. You're a smart man. They want to trade the son for his poppa.
Rat flicks a folded letter through the air. Badger catche it. He opens it. Kylie looks over his shoulder. Badger frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd they write this in letters cut out of magazines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: To protect their identities. (on second thought) Oh, right, but then why'd they sign their names? Plus, we already knew who they were because they're trying to kill us.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A ransom note written in letters cut out of magazines and pasted onto a piece of paper. Badger reads out loud: Mr. Fox, we have your son. If you ever want to see him alive again -- Ash calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm his son. Everyone looks at Ash. He stands behind them in silhouett Rat says darkly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see the resemblance. Pause. In an instant, Rat grabs Ash by the tail, picks hi off the ground, swings him in the air, and flings him awa twenty feet down the drainpipe. Badger looks stunned. Ash sits in a puddle in a stupor. Rat races toward him do the tunnel. He leaps into the air with his claws out and teeth bared. As he is about to seize upon Ash -- he is suddenly jerked backwards and spun around. Rat is face to face with Fox. Fox strikes his old-fashion boxing stance. He draws back and throws a hard punch, nai Rat square in the jaw. Rat staggers, stunned. He swings h switchblade, cutting Fox across the chest. Fox touches the wound and looks at the blood on the finge of his paw. He looks to Rat. Rat holds up his wrist and s Fox a child's plastic digital watch with miniature footba baseballs, and soccer balls on it. He says strangely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've still got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What'd you just say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I said I've still got the watch, Mr. Fox. She never asked for it back. A frozen moment. Fox springs forward and clamps his jaws Rat's throat. Rat tumbles over backwards. Fox pins him to ground with his teeth in Rat's neck. Rat kicks and bucks struggles, but Fox holds him fast. Rat goes limp. Fox releases him. Everyone slowly gathers around Fox and Rat. Ash kneels ne to his father. Fox cradles Rat in his arms. Rat whispers:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The boy's locked in an apple crate on top of a gun-locker in the attic of Bean Annex. It's a set-up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Would you have told me if I didn't kill you first? Rat smiles sickly. Blood drips from his mouth. His voice

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Never.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (shaking his head) All these wasted years. What were you looking for, Rat? Fox wipes the blood from Rat's chin. Rat mutters.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's trying to say something, Dad. Fox leans his ear close to Rat's mouth. As quiet as a mou

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cider.
Fox nods. He looks around the drainpipe. He cups his paw the pool of murky water and holds it to Rat's lips.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Here you are, Rat. A beaker of Bean's finest secret cider. Rat's slivery, scratchity, long, pink tongue laps up a ta of the black liquid. He licks his lips and says faintly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Like melted gold. Rat's eyes turn into X's. He is dead. Ash stands up.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He redeemed himself.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Redemption? Sure. Fox swallows and says hopelessly with tears in his eyes:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: But, in the end -- he's just another dead rat in a garbage pail behind a Chinese restaurant. Ash puts his hand on Fox's shoulder. Fox lays Rat gently the sewer floor. He stands up and turns to the rest of th group. Badger claps his paws together.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I suppose we should --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me, again, B. The search party's been cancelled. We're replacing it with a go-for-broke rescue mission. It's a set- up, but maybe we can make it work. You two little rabbits run tell the others.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Now, go! The two little rabbits scurry away down the drainpipe. Ba walks with Fox and Ash.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What was he saying about that wristwatch? I didn't get what he was talking about.
Fox hesitates. He shrugs and says with a sad nostalgia:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Just some old back-story.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The entire community of animals has reconnoitered in the brick cavern. Fox stands on a large spigot and addresses group. He has a bandage on his chest.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: In a way, I'm almost glad that flood interrupted us, because I don't like the toast I was giving. I'm going to start over. Fox pantomimes raising a long-stemmed glass.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When I look down this table with the exquisite feast set before us, I see: two terrific lawyers, a skilled pediatrician, a wonderful chef, a savvy real-estate agent, an excellent tailor, a crack accountant, a gifted musician, a pretty good minnow fisherman, and possibly the best landscape painter working on the scene today. As Fox describes them, the shot cuts to: Badger and Beave Mrs. Badger; Rabbit; Weasel; an especially small, waifish field mouse; Mole; Kylie (who looks slightly offended); a Mrs. Fox, respectively.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Maybe a few of you might even read my column from time to time. Who knows? I tend to doubt it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I also see a room full of wild animals. Everyone stares at Fox curiously, skeptical but intrigued Fox points at them:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Wild animals with true natures and pure talents. Wild animals with scientific- sounding Latin names that mean something about our D.N.A. Wild animals each with his own strengths and weaknesses due to his or her species, and also -- well, I guess these things usually have a lot to

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: do with the parents, as we all know. Anyway, I think it may very well be all the beautiful differences among us that just might give us the tiniest glimmer of a chance of saving my nephew and letting me make it up to you for getting us into this crazy whatever-it-is. I don't know. It's just a thought. Thank you for listening. Cheers, everyone. Fox motions with his imaginary glass and pantomimes drink it. A few of the others reluctantly pantomime drinking. F finishes his glass and pantomimes throwing it on the floo He makes a smashing-glass sound. Kylie shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's eat! Everyone turns to Kylie uncertainly. Kylie hesitates.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? I'm just playing along with the --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Let's start planning! Who knows shorthand? Pause. Badger points to his otter secretary. She is Linda Fox darts over to her and grips her by the arm.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Linda! Lutra Lutra! You got some dry paper? Here we go! Fox, highly energized, moves among the group, touching th shoulders and patting their backs.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mole! Talpa Europea! What do you got?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can see in the dark?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's incredible! We can use that! Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit! Oryctolagus Cuniculus!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm fast.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You bet your cuss you are! Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Beaver! Castor Fiber!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I can chew through wood.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Amazing! Linda?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badger! Meles Meles!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demolitions expert!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Since when?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Explosions, flames, things that burn!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Demolitions expert! OK! Linda!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it! Fox's cheeks and forehead are beaded with perspiration. H

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Weasel! Mustela Nivalis!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stop yelling! Fox snaps his fingers, kicks a rock, and throws his arm i the air.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All right! Fox points to the various cubs and pups.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: All you little kids get organized and put together some kind of a K.P. unit or something to keep this sewer clean. It's good for morale. The field mouse shoves his way to the front of the crowd. makes a fist with his paw.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I want to go with you, too! I want to fight!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Good. Fabulous! Microtus Pennsylvanicus! Do you do that, in fact? Are field mice violent?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not particularly, except maybe domestic/ kitchen sink-type stuff, but I have a hunch I might just --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- land a few good punches before I get stepped on, poisoned, or lured to my death by a little piece of cheese. Who's to say?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (smiling with admiration) You're a cuss of a lot bigger than you look, Rickity. Kylie tugs at Fox's sleeve. Fox turns to look at him. Kyl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't get a job yet -- or a Latin name. What's my strength? Fox raises an eyebrow. He thinks of something:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Listen, you're Kylie. You're an unbelievably nice guy. Your job is really just to... be available, I think. I don't know your Latin name. I doubt they even had opossums in ancient Rome. Kylie puts his hands in his pockets and scowls.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fox puts the finishing touches on a vast mural paint on the longest, tallest wall of the brick cavern. She sta on a ladder. Her sleeves are rolled up, and she is splatt with twelve different colors of paint. She looks down to standing below with an entourage of Kylie, Badger, Linda, Rickity. The animal children mop and scrub in the backgro Ash stands leaning against a push-broom watching his pare Fox surveys the mural. It is highly detailed, filled with textures of the landscape, and decorated with images of flowers, leaves, acorns, etc. It is signed Felicity Fox. opens his arms wide and shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: It's stupendous. Where's us?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: (pointing to a spot) Right here.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Paint an X.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The bottom of the map. Mrs. Fox's paw paints a red X and a circle around it. The shot zooms out to reveal the entire valley -- no long painting on the brick wall. Lighting strikes at the horiz Dark clouds loom over the three farmers' compounds. It lo exactly like one of Mrs. Fox's paintings of a landscape i rainstorm. Bean's helicopter circles the area.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. HILL. NIGHT
dialogues.text: A bicycle messenger with a head-lamp rings his bell as he approaches the farmers' camp. He stops in front of Bean a hands him an envelope. Bean tears it open and unfolds the letter inside.

A note written in letters cut out of magazines and pasted onto a piece of paper. It reads: Dear Farmers Boggis, Bunce, and Bean, I have no alternative but to agree to your terms. Move the station wagon and open the manhole cover below the foot of the drainpipe next to the cobbler's shop and meet me there today at 10 A.M. sharp. I will hand myself over to you in exchange for the boy's safe return. Cordially, Mr. Fox Bean frowns. He studies the letter. He shows it to Boggis Bunce.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why'd he write this in letters cut out of magazines?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't know, but you did the same thing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't trust this guy. Anyway, set up the ambush.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC. DAY
dialogues.text: The top floor of Bean Annex. The room is filled with boxe Christmas ornaments, old sports equipment, two stained mattresses, and a broken birdcage. Cobwebs hang from the rafters below the sloped roof. Kristofferson stands with his hands in his pockets lookin out between the slats from inside a padlocked apple crate top of a gun locker in the corner. He clears his throat. calls out politely:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Could I have a cup of water, please? Kristofferson waits for a reply, but no one answers. He whistles to himself for a minute. He clears his throat ag He calls out:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Excuse me?
Silence.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAINPIPE. DAY
dialogues.text: A cement conduit with an iron grating above it. A fast st of sewer water runs along its side. Fox walks briskly dow the pipe followed by his entourage and Ash. Their steps e loudly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Synchronize your clocks. The time is

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox looks at his wrist. He is wearing Rat's plastic, digi sports-themed wristwatch.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- nine forty-five A.M. Everyone checks their watches. Badger points at Fox's wri

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that Rat's watch?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No. Originally, no.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, OK, here's the back-story: when I was a teenager I spent a summer working as a bar-back at a jazz pub called Django's where Rat played horn down near -- can I tell this another time? We should stay focused on what's happening right now. Ash comes up to Fox's side and says discreetly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I should probably ride with you and Kylie since it's my fault Kristofferson got captured stealing those nutmeg-ginger- apple snaps.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I didn't understand a word of that sentence, but none of it matters, anyway, because it's too dangerous for you to come with us.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: An old craftsman looks out from the window of Ferguson Cobblers as he taps little nails into the heel of a loafe station-wagon with wood-grain side-panels and a flat tire sits parked on a manhole cover in front of the shop. Bogg Bunce, and five armed farmhands watch as Bean monkeys wit slim-jim until he gets the car door jimmied. Bean hops inside. He starts the engine, puts his arm over top of the seat as he looks back out the rear window, and throws the station-wagon into reverse. The farmers clear of the way as Bean backs up off the manhole cover. Boggis and Bunce stick tools into the manhole cover and l it open.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rat's watch. It is now 10 A.M.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Six armed farmhands on the roof of the Nag's Head Tavern.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Seven armed farmhands in the bushes behind Sweetings Bake

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Eight armed farmers in the window of Harrison Travel.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The Action 13 reporter and camera crew in an alley next t St. John's Coin-op Laundry.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Boggis, Bunce, and Bean crouch behind the open doors of a pick-up truck with three beagles. Boggis checks his carbi Bunce loads his shotgun. Bean cocks his Luger. Fox's voic hollers from deep inside the manhole:

dialogues.speaker: FOX, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Did you bring the boy?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Of course, we did! Say something, kid! Bunce presses play on a tape recorder. Kristofferson's vo comes over a loudspeaker:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Excuse me! Excuse me? Bunce presses stop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and his entourage at the bottom off the manhole. Fox scoffs. He smiles and shakes his head.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on! That doesn't sound anything like him! It's amateur night in Dixie! Badger rapidly slaps two pieces of flint together. A bit chips off, and sparks fly from the break. He blows on som kindling. He takes a pinecone out of a basket.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: A ribbon of white smoke rises out of the manhole. The thr farmers watch curiously as it thickens and turns black. B frowns.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What the cuss is he burning? A blazing pinecone shoots out of the manhole and flies through the air, over the farmers' heads. It lands in a t can and lights some rubbish on fire. A man with a dart in hand and a mug of ale in the other comes out of the Nag's Head and pours his beer into the trash can. The fire goes out. The three farmers laugh smugly. Bean shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is that all you've got, Mr. Fox? Twenty-seven blazing pinecones shoot out of the manhole a hit: a wood-pile on the roof of the Nag's Head, a box of pastry wrappers in the bushes behind Sweetings, a stack o brochures in the window of Harrison Travel, a hay bale in bed of the pick-up truck, Boggis, Bunce, Bean, and a crat cam-corder batteries next to the Action 13 camera crew, w explodes. Farmers scatter, grabbing hoses, yelling, and tamping out the flames as the beagles bark, yelp, and scramble in the confusion. Rabbit darts out of the hole and races up the street. Six farmers chase after him, firing their weapons.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. DAY
dialogues.text: Down in the brick cavern, Mole listens to a tin can attac to a string. He says urgently as he makes notations in a

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Twenty-eight pinecones fired! Twenty-two targets hit! Mrs. Fox, standing on her ladder, paints black checks qui on the street in her mural. The stolen, portable televisi set sits in the corner, tuned into Action 13's coverage o the chaos in the street.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit running full-steam out of the village being pursue the six farmhands. He hurdles an empty Coke bottle lying its side in the road.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Badger jumps out of the manhole and throws more blazing pinecones at farmers, trucks, parked cars, doors, windows and the Action 13 camera crew. Seven farmhands chase him a cobblestone lane. Weasel and Beaver climb out with straws in their paws and start firing blueberries toward the disoriented beagles. beagles eat blueberries. They fall over. Eight farmhands chase Weasel and Beaver up a wooded path. Rickity, the field mouse, bounds out of the hole and leap into the fracas. He fires a rubber band at Bunce off a paperclip. It snaps Bunce in the corner of his eye. Ricki lets out a little whoop. There is a small explosion and a burst of flames blasts f the manhole. Fox and Kylie jump out and run over to a veh with a tarp over it parked in front of Paddington Automot Fox whips off the tarp, revealing a miniature motorcycle a sidecar.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox driving the motorcycle with Kylie in the sidecar. The both wear helmets and goggles. Thunder rumbles in the distance. Kylie sinks lower in the sidecar. He shouts to over the sound of the motor:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Are you scared of wolves?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Scared, no! I have a phobia of them!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, I have a thing about thunder!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why? That's stupid! Ash pokes his head up from the rear compartment of the sidecar. He also wears a helmet and goggles. His white ca flutters behind him. He shouts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't like needles! Fox and Kylie look to Ash in disbelief. Fox says furiousl

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you come from again? How'd you get in the sidecar? I feel like I'm losing my mind! Fox angrily steers toward a small mound of dirt. They jum slightly and fly over a little ditch. Ash yelps enthusiastically as Fox drives them back onto the road.

dialogues.speaker: INT. HELICOPTER. DAY
dialogues.text: A pilot with a red moustache and a South African accent f Bean's chopper. He wears a Bean, inc. patch on his should He shouts into the microphone connected to his helmet:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I've got a fox on a motorcycle with a littler fox and what looks to be an opossum in the sidecar riding north on farm lane seven. Does that sound like anything to anybody? A military-type voice responds over the radio:

dialogues.speaker: MILITARY VOICE, (O.S.)
dialogues.text: Roger that, Red. Let me just, uh -- Oh, I think the boss wants to --

dialogues.speaker: BEAN, (0.S.)
dialogues.text: Red, it's Franklin Bean! Turn around, get the cuss back here, and pick us up on the

dialogues.speaker: EXT. BEAN'S COMPOUND. DAY
dialogues.text: The Bean, inc. windmill spins briskly in the dusty winds. Shutters on the farmhouse bang open and shut. Leaves rust on the branches of the apple trees. A few stray turkeys wander in the yard. A white-washed brick pile six stories tall sits apart from the other structures. The doors to i courtyard are made of iron and painted yellow. This is Be Annex. The front gates of the farm are open, and a gardener wate vegetables next to the driveway. Fox, Kylie, and Ash look from a high branch over a reinforced concrete and barbed- security barricade.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's the annex over there on the right. Ash nods. Kylie does not respond.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white building over there on the right. Pause. Fox looks to Kylie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kylie? Kylie turns to Fox and stares at him vacantly. Fox says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kylie!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I did it!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: When? I didn't see it! Kylie makes his slight gesture with his paw. The gardener puts three turnips into a basket and rides away on his bicycle. Fox, Kylie, and Ash scramble down the tree trunk. They co out of the bushes on their motorcycle and ride through th gates, across the yard, past the wandering turkeys. They outside the courtyard doors to Bean Annex and jump off th motorcycle.
Fox climbs onto Kylie's shoulders and tries the knobs. Th are locked.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kylie, you got a credit card?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (digging in his pockets) Sure.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: See, this is what I was saying about how good you are at just being available for

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kylie hands Fox a World Traveler Titanium Card. Fox frown

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A Titanium Card? How the cuss did you qualify for this?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I pay my bills on time. I've always had good credit. Fox examines the card with mild resentment. He picks the and opens the doors. The courtyard has high walls and a gravel floor. On one s there are ten trash cans, a stack of newspapers, and a compost heap. On the other side, there is an old, rusted, broken-down tractor and a new one. By far the largest, fattest, toughest beagle yet lies sleeping in the middle. White foam froths around its mouth as it breathes heavily Its collar is hooked to a thick chain. A tag around its n reads Spitz. Fox, Kylie, and Ash stop in their tracks. The beagle open his eyes. Fox turns to Kylie.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Give me a blueberry. Kylie looks surprised. He shrugs. He shakes his head and gestures, I don't have any. Fox frowns. He throws up his hands in the air. Kylie makes a frustrated face. Fox poin at him. Kylie looks away and snorts angrily. Fox looks aw and spits at the ground. Ash says quietly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What's that white stuff around his mouth?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think he eats soap. Fox sees an amber, plastic pharmacy bottle on a shelf abo some bags of fertilizer. It's reads: Drug: Phenomoxylcarbobubytol, 10 mg

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: For: RABIES (chronic) Other: Take with meat, do not operate heavy machinery Fox frowns. He says grimly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's not soap.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Well, then why does he have that bubbly --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's rabid. With rabies. I've heard about this beagle. The beagle stands up. Fox says carefully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Easy, boy. Fox takes a cautious step toward the beagle. He holds out back of his paw for the beagle to sniff. He says back ove his shoulder to Kylie and Ash:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm going to try to befriend him. I feel like there's a tenderness in his eyes. Fox takes another step. He makes a soft, kissing noise. T beagle watches him calmly.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yes, I'm right. He's a good boy. A little lonely, maybe, but -- Fox takes another cautious step.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- but terribly sweet. Hello, there, boy. Is your name Spitz? That's German, isn't it?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (aside, to Ash) I thought he said you never look a beagle in the eye.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why, you're just as sweet as a -- Fox and the beagle lock eyes. The pupils of the beagle's contract then completely disappear, and the whites turn bright red. Fox's eyes open wider than their sockets. The rabid beagle erupts ballistically, attacking like an enraged maniac. His chain rips out of the cement. Fox, Ky and Ash shriek and scream, sprinting frantically around t courtyard as the rabid beagle, frothing, roaring, and snapping, tries desperately to kill them. Fox shouts, his voice cracking like a grandmother's:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Climb the trellis! In well under a second, Fox, Kylie, and Ash scale the tre six stories -- Kylie's pants catching on a nail and rippi off on the way up -- and find themselves standing on the of Bean Annex. Kylie wears blue Fruit-of-the-Looms with a pattern of stars, moons, and planets on them. They all lo down at the rabid beagle, which continues to pitch an ins fit, running in circles after its tail at the bottom of t courtyard. Fox takes in their new surroundings. He says, pleased:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: So the attic is probably in the area right up around here somewhere, I figure, huh? Kylie and Ash, panting and dripping with sweat, both star Fox vacantly. (NOTE: a second set of alternate eyeballs indicating Kyli vacant look will be used for Ash in this shot.)

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Come on, guys. Stay with me. We did good. That's just some dog. Let's not get traumatized.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROOF. DAY
dialogues.text: Bean's helicopter lands on top of the Nag's Head. Fires smolder and farmers continue to chase around after animal the village streets below. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean, leani over and holding onto their hats, run to the chopper and climb inside. They take off.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The street below. An orange and yellow Citroen van screec into the melee. Painted yellow letters spell Badoit et Fi Destruction des Animaux Nuisibles on the side of it with image of a trapped fox. An old man with a grey moustache and a young man with a b moustache, both dressed in orange-and-yellow-striped uniforms, jump out of the van. They open the side door an start unloading stacks of metal cages.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit still running full-steam down a country lane being pursued by the six farmhands.

dialogues.speaker: INT. ATTIC. DAY
dialogues.text: Kristofferson stands inside the apple crate leaning again the wall with his legs crossed and one arm akimbo with hi hand on his hip. There is a clanking sound from above. Kristofferson looks up. A trap door in the ceiling creaks open. Fox, Kylie, and A look inside, down at Kristofferson. Kristofferson smiles oddly and says in a surprised, fancy-meeting-you-here voi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hi!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Fox and Kylie lowering Ash into the room with three diffe colored shoelaces tied together and belted around his wai Ash holds the shoelace and keeps a paw behind his back li mountaineer. His feet touch down on the shelf. He runs to apple crate and jiggles the padlock. He hesitates. He say

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Can I get one of those karate lessons real quick?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: OK. Normally, we start with some breathing exercises and such. Stand like this. Kristofferson stands with his paws clasped in front of hi Ash mimics this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A fox-trap hanging from a chain suspended above the alley behind the Nag's Head Tavern. A second one hangs behind Sweetings Bakery. A third one hangs behind Harrison Trave fourth one hangs behind St. John's Coin-op Laundry. A fif one hangs behind Ferguson Cobblers. Rickity curiously examines a little, hanging wire. He mut

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Is this spring-loaded?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson continuing Ash's karate lesson:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This next part is mental. Position yourself on the balls of your feet. Kristofferson stands lightly poised with his arms out. As mimics this.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Close your eyes. Kristofferson closes his eyes. So does Ash. So do Fox and Kylie. Kristofferson says mystically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You weigh less than a slice of bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each fox-trap in rapid succession as it falls on: Rickity Badger, Weasel, and Beaver. The two small rabbits watch f a sewer-gutter drain under the street-curb. They panic. T race down a pipe, into a tunnel, and through a conduit.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson continuing Ash's karate lesson:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's review the principle agility techniques: jumping, flipping, landing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fox looking down from her ladder at the three, panti rabbits. She looks stunned. She motions to her mural/map

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Show me where they are!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The two small rabbits, Mrs. Rabbit, Mrs. Badger, Mole, an Mrs. Fox each furiously digging a new tunnel.

dialogues.speaker: KRISTOFFERSON, (V.0.)
dialogues.text: Now for a rudimentary version of the cyclone chop.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Kristofferson continuing Ash's karate lesson:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: First, you need to get a running start, which, obviously, I can't do in here, then, as you arrive at the destination of the chop --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- lean and thrust into the point of contact, paw remains open and straight, then withdraw instantaneously. Remember, it's the pull-back that matters. The pull-

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- generates the force of the impact.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Got it. Ash walks ten paces away to the far end of the shelf. Fox Kylie watch from above. Kylie says excitedly:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He's going to do it! Fox makes a face that says, I'm not so sure. Ash takes a breath. He screams at the top of his lungs as he sprints toward the apple crate:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-ya! Ash's toe catches on a loose nail. He somersaults twice through the air and bounces off the side of the apple cra which falls off the shelf. Kristofferson braces himself. The apple crate hits the fl and shatters into pieces. Kristofferson lies among the wreckage. Ash looks over the side of the shelf. Fox and Kylie watch from above, grimacing.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm sorry.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right. You were just trying to unlock the apple crate.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: No, I mean I'm sorry about --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: (picking himself up) Oh, you mean from before. The apology you owed me which you never actually said.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah. Kristofferson nods sadly. He takes a deep breath. He nods again.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: That's all right, too. Throw me the shoelace, please. Ash smiles.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badger trapped in his cage. He hears something. He looks quickly down the alley. The old, orange van turns the cor and approaches, bumping over potholes. Badger shrinks int the corner of the cage and mutters grimly to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Badoit et fils.

A cobblestone beside Badger suddenly drops straight down disappears into the ground. Badger recoils, scared and confused. Mrs. Fox pokes her head up through the hole. She is beade with perspiration and breathes heavily. Her fur is wildly dishevelled. She looks to the van driving up the alley. S looks to Badger. She extends her paw to him and says

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Let's go!

dialogues.speaker: EXT. YARD. DAY
dialogues.text: Fox, Kylie, Ash, and Kristofferson come around the side o the building. They run to their motorcycle, outside the courtyard doors. They freeze. The front gates to the compound are closed and bolted. Be helicopter waits on top of the vegetable garden with its rotar-blades whirling. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean stand in f of Bean Annex with their weapons drawn. Fox sees his tail around Bean's collar. His eyes narrow. jaw sets. He says to himself with growing emotion:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Your tractors uprooted my tree. Your posse hunted my family. Your gunmen kidnapped my nephew. Your rat insulted my wife -- and you shot off my tail.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm not leaving here without that neck- tie. Bean smiles his sickly smile. Fox smiles back defiantly. Kylie looks utterly baffled. Ash says mystically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I weigh less than a slice of bread.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'll be right back. Ash runs. Fox, Kylie, and Kristofferson watch, shocked, a Ash sprints back to the courtyard doors. The three farmer open fire at him. Fox, Kylie, and Kristofferson duck and cover behind a hay-bale.

Ash dodges bullets. He jumps off the balls of his feet wi his arms out over a sprinkler-pipe and swings like a gymn onto a clothesline, then flies through the air doing anot of his spectacularly awkward four-armed and three-legged flips. He lands on the handle of one of the courtyard doo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ki-ya! Ash cyclone-chops the doorknob. The lock clicks. Ash's ey light up. Ash drops to the ground. He digs a hole and burrows into dirt as bullets fly everywhere. He breathes in through hi nose and out through his mouth. Fox watches with his jaw hanging open. The courtyard doors smash apart and the rabid beagle tear out into the vegetable garden growling, foaming, and thrashing crazily. The farmers shriek and scream and run around, panicking, with their guns blazing. Fox, Kylie, Ash, and Kristofferson jump onto their motorcycle. The beagle rips the tail from Bean's neck, sh it, chews it up, and swallows it. Fox deflates for an instant, then recovers. He looks to Ash on the back of th motorcycle, behind him, with his hands around Fox's waist says with the deepest affection and respect:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Ash, that was pure, wild animal craziness. You're an athlete. Ash swallows. He beams. He sits up straighter. (NOTE: from this point onwards, an alternate version of A will be used which is slightly taller, slightly leaner, a animated slightly more gracefully.) Fox kick-starts the motorcycle and races across the farm. Boggis, Bunce, and Bean scramble onto the roof of a car p with an old, white Mercedes convertible under it. The snarling beagle barks and snaps below them. They watch as Fox steers the motorcycle toward a broken apple cart at t edge of the property. He guns the motor and yells:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Holy swearing cuss!!!
Fox races the motorcycle up the apple cart, into the air, over the concrete barricade. They land in the middle of t road, skidding, and speed off down the hill.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Boggis, Bunce, and Bean watching from the roof of the car port. Boggis turns to Bean and says, deadpan, needling hi

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Franklin? You got any final twist for this plot?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Yeah! Bean grabs Boggis by the neck and throttles him. Bunce st throwing punches. Bean holds him back by the forehead. Bo kicks Bunce in the stomach. They brawl chaotically while rabid beagle continues to go bananas below them.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Each fox-trap with a cobblestone missing underneath it an hole in the ground. The old man with the grey moustache t to his son and says with a strong French accent:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Cuss.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SEWER SYSTEM. DAY
dialogues.text: Mrs. Fox sits anxiously at the bottom of her ladder. Badg Weasel, Rickity, the two small rabbits, and the others si exhausted, in the dark cavern, passing a jar of cider. Mo

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Stand by! Everyone looks to Mole. Mole is holding the tin can with string attached to it to his ear. He nods and says urgent

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I just intercepted a high-frequency radio signal with the can -- (gestures with the tin can) -- and I think they're on their way home!
Mrs. Fox jumps up, embraces Mole, and kisses him on the snout. Mole blushes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Rabbit still running full-steam back into the village bei pursued by the six farmhands. He comes to the manhole whe they started and darts into it. The six farmhands stop at manhole and look down. They go straight to the Nag's Head walk inside, and close the door behind them.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. ROAD. DAY
dialogues.text: Fox, Kylie, Ash, and Kristofferson ride down a country ro Kylie sees something across the meadow. He says warily:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Don't turn around!

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What? Fox turns around. A huge, wild, grey wolf with ice-blue e stands on a rock fifty feet away from them. Fox slams on brakes. The motorcycle slides to a halt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd he come from?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where'd you come from? What are you doing here? Pause. Fox points toward the wolf:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Canis lupus! Fox points to himself:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Vulpes Vulpes! The wolf does not answer. Fox, Kylie, Ash, and Kristoffer watch idling from the motorcycle.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I don't think he speaks English or Latin.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Pensez-vous que 1'hiver sera rude?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I'm asking if he thinks we're in for a hard winter.
The wolf shakes his head. Fox nods.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: He doesn't seem to know. Silence. Fox shouts to the wolf with a strange hitch in h

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I have a phobia of wolves! The wolf does not answer. It breathes heavily with its mo open. Its teeth are long, sharp, and yellow. Its tongue h out, and its eyes are wild. Fox looks back at it with the identical expression for a minute, mesmerized -- then Fox closes his mouth and his eyes soften. Fox raises his paw in the air. The wolf blinks a few time It raises its paw in the air. It turns away and trots off into the woods. Fox says wistfully:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: What a beautiful creature. Wish him luck, boys. Fox guns the motor. Gravel spits from under the spinning tires, and they tear off down the road. The shot booms do into the ground, below the grass, through buried pebbles, layers of soil, and subterranean mineral deposits.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: THREE DAYS LATER (2 1/2 Fox Weeks) The shot continues to descend past Badger and his family having dinner in a nicely furnished drain-pipe, past Rabb and his family watching Magnum, P.I. on the stolen, porta television set in a well-appointed cement tunnel, past Be and Mrs. Beaver hosting Mole and Weasel for cocktails in tasteful sewer-conduit. The shot stops in a small chamber adjacent to the brick cavern. The walls are filled with electrical cables, wire pipes, and a large, new mural which depicts the Fox's for view of the valley as seen from their tree with a trompe 1'oeil window-frame around it. It is signed Felicity Fox. Ash and Kristofferson sit Indian-style meditating on a braided rug. Mrs. Fox works mixing paints and turpentine an easel in the corner. There is an armchair with a folde copy of the Gazette on its cushion in the center of the r under a glowing lamp. Classical music plays on a radio.
Fox swings his head into the room from a tunnel. He says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: My darlings? Everyone looks to Fox. He signals them to follow him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. DRAINPIPE. NIGHT
dialogues.text: The cement conduit with the iron grating above it. Fox an his family walk briskly down the pipe. A knitted, woolen, artificial tail has been sewn into the seat of Fox's trousers.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Where are we going?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Nobody knows.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: We were in the middle of a meditation practice.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Watch your step. Fox takes everyone through an opening and starts climbing metal ladder. He says theatrically:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Let's see, now. Where does this lead?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Oh, no, Foxy. It's filthy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Keep a good grip, everyone.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: This better be worth it.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I think I see a little sliver of light. What's this? Is that a door?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You're a terrible actor, Foxy.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Do you smell something? Is that --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: -- freon?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Shh. I'm going to crack open this trap door and see if something's on the other side. I highly doubt it, though. There's probably just more sewer. Fox clears his throat. Pause.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: You know, wouldn't it be surprising if --

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Open it. Fox pushes open the trap door and crawls out. Everyone follows him.

dialogues.speaker: INT. SUPERMARKET. NIGHT
dialogues.text: Fox and his family stand in the middle of an aisle at the center of a large grocery store. To their left is the refrigerated section of milk, eggs, meat, fish, and chees To their right are canned goods, breakfast cereal, laundr detergent, rice, pasta, and condiments. The lights are ha dimmed, and a metal grate is closed over the front window There are no people. Fox says casually:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Hey, look! There's a whole, enormous, glorious, gigantic supermarket up here! Ash and Kristofferson seem dumbstruck. Fox raises an eyeb and smiles at Mrs. Fox. She puts her arm around his shoul

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: You really are kind of a quote-unquote fantastic fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: I try. I guess now that Kristofferson's dad's already down to single-pneumonia and getting better, he'll be going home soon, huh?

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: Actually, when he spoke to me from the hospital, he said he was already talking
MRS. FOX (cont'd) to Weasel about real-estate availabil- ities down in our sewer system.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, really? Well, now's the time to buy. Kylie comes around the end of the aisle pushing a miniatu shopping cart filled with jars of jelly, jam, olives, pickles, and honey, plus three loaves of bread, Band-Aids toothpaste, and a carton of strawberry ice cream. He says

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Did I hear my name?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Not down here, you didn't.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Why not?

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Because we were talking about other things.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Oh, well. Fox looks at Ash, who is studying a twelve-pack of tropic juice punch-boxes.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: The white cape rather suits him, doesn't it? Actually, I had to do quite a bit of searching myself before I found a look that really flattered me. Remember those horseshoe cuff-links? Fox and Mrs. Fox crack-up laughing. Fox notices something stops. He stares at Mrs. Fox strangely. She is glowing. S hesitates. She shrugs.

dialogues.speaker: MRS. FOX
dialogues.text: I'm pregnant again. Fox is confused and moved. He holds Mrs. Fox's face in hi paws. She smiles. Ash interrupts:

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Dad?
Fox and Mrs. Fox look to Ash. An empty punch-box lies on side behind him with a straw sticking out of it. There is huge, purple stain all over the front of his white shirt.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: Should we dance? Pause. Everyone breaks out giddily dancing an ecstatic ji Kylie waltzes the cart in circles. Fox spins Mrs. Fox.

dialogues.speaker: Unknown
dialogues.text: A wide shot of all sixteen aisles of the supermarket stac with boxes, cartons, cans, bottles, bags, and jars of eve possible variety of food. The family of foxes continues t dance at the distant end of the center aisle.

dialogues.speaker: EXT. STREET. DAY
dialogues.text: Boggis, Bunce, and Bean sit silently in folding metal cha around the manhole. Boggis's carbine rests across his lap Bunce's shotgun hangs from a strap over his shoulder. Bea cleans his Luger. Petey sits on a cider box outside the N Head strumming his guitar in the background. The bartende pulls the shutters shut and flips a sign on the door to Closed. Petey starts singing his song as the credits roll The sun sets. The farmers sit waiting in the dark.
